urls.title: 2021 ICA Conference Fee Waiver Application Form for MCIG Members
urls.description: Hooray, the 2021 ICA conference is coming soon in May! And the MCIG leadership would like to grant conference fee waivers to 5 MCIG members. Priority is given to students and young scholars who are residing and studying/working in Tier B countries (e.g., countries such as Argentina, Mexico, South Africa) and to scholars who are experiencing financial hardship and would otherwise not be able to attend the conference. Scholars in Tier C countries (e.g., Cameroon, Ghana, Myanmar, India, Vietnam) already have free access to the conference this year. (The Tier System determined by the ICA is published here for your reference: https://www.icahdq.org/general/custom.asp?page=tiers )

I got my #ica21 reviews back and I CANNOT BELIEVE THIS: "You're [sic] article is nicely written, almost too nice for scientific purposes. I suggest to sacrifice prose-style for dry clarity."

I pour my heart & soul into research, so naturally I struggle with taking rejections personally. Never forget a rejection =/= bad paper.

Say it with me #ICA21: You have value. Rejections bear no impact on you as a person, an academic, or a scholar.

Stay strong & keep the faith! https://t.co/nxsQiJVMZJ https://t.co/pxxn6KgZEw

tweets.text: second year in a row rejected by #ica21 !! if you're smarting over rejections please know it happens to all of us!

To emphasize again:

Rejected Article (4.12/5): Overall great work! Interesting study with innovative approach, offers important theoretical & practical implications regarding comm & political PR.

Accepted Paper (3.9/5): Arguments & findings are ordinary & underwhelming.

#ICA21 https://t.co/jPWBE8l4FL
Big thanks to all the reviewers for #ica21. Despite these difficult times, I received some seriously thoughtful suggestions that will help me move this research forward üôè

To reemphasize this: my rejected paper had a higher average reviewer rating (4.12) than did my accepted paper (3.9). 

While it's a gut check for sure, don't let rejections hold you down or discourage you from doing what you want to do in research! #ICA21 https://t.co/LW4m2dccYF

Still can't believe that my first-authored submission with @ConsumerSurv got accepted for #ica21! Very excited to join everyone for the #virtual conference in May!

Sad to see my paper was not accepted for ICA but ready to read the reviews and improve the project! Work is always in progress and feedback is valuable! Congratulations to all who have accepted work for #ica21 !!

The short turnaround between #ica21 submission and feedback (@icahdq is the fastest conference I submit to) coupled with the helpful reviews, means that I am able to directly and immediately apply referee feedback to my ongoing research projects. What an AWESOME benefit! (5/n)

I'm also thankful for the @icahdq leadership. #ica21 reviews were due 6 Nov. In less than 10 weeks, submissions were evaluated, the conference was planned, and scores were returned to submitters. This is faster than many journals! (4/n)

First, THANK YOU to everyone who completed #ica21 reviews for @ICA_CSaB. I say this yearly, but reviews in our interest group are among the best at @icahdq. The reviews (especially the critical ones) were thoughtful and provided helpful feedback that I can immediately apply (2/n)

And finally, a BIG thank YOU to @allison_eden who planned the #ica21 conference for @ICA_CSaB. As Vice Chair, I've had a sneak peak and the schedule and let me tell you, @ICA_CSaB has an incredible lineup this year (6/n)

I'm particularly thankful for these #ica21 reviews given that referees returned their evaluations quickly, during a remarkably difficult time, and that the @ICA_CSaB community came together for to provide careful and detailed feedback. Our community honors its commitments! (3/n)
